metadata.subject: chemistry
metadata.dotPoint: IR spectroscopy for identifying functional groups via characteristic absorption bands

ir-absorption.name: IR Absorption Mechanism
ir-absorption.correct: IR radiation causes bonds to vibrate at characteristic frequencies

ionises molecules.error: Confusing IR with ionisation - IR causes vibration, not ionisation
ionises molecules.fix: IR radiation is lower energy than UV/visible and causes molecular vibrations, not electron removal
ionises molecules.action: Remember: IR = infrared = vibration; UV = higher energy = ionisation

breaks chemical bonds.error: Confusing absorption with bond breaking - IR stretches bonds, not breaks them
breaks chemical bonds.fix: IR energy causes bonds to stretch and bend but is insufficient to break bonds
breaks chemical bonds.action: Think of bonds vibrating like springs - they stretch but don't snap

excites electrons.error: Confusing IR with UV-visible - IR affects bonds, UV affects electrons
excites electrons.fix: IR radiation causes bond vibrations; UV-visible radiation excites electrons
excites electrons.action: Match: IR → vibrations, UV-vis → electronic transitions

persistent.gap: Not understanding that IR causes molecular vibrations
persistent.action: Focus on how bonds act like springs that stretch and bend when absorbing IR

wavenumber.name: Wavenumber Scale
wavenumber.correct: Wavenumber measured in cm⁻¹ with higher values indicating higher energy

wavelength in nm.error: Using wavelength units instead of wavenumber - IR uses cm⁻¹
wavelength in nm.fix: IR spectra display wavenumber (cm⁻¹) not wavelength; wavenumber is inversely proportional to wavelength
wavelength in nm.action: Note x-axis labels: IR spectra always show wavenumber in cm⁻¹

frequency in Hz.error: Using frequency units - IR spectra use wavenumber convention
frequency in Hz.fix: While related to frequency, IR spectra conventionally use wavenumber (cm⁻¹)
frequency in Hz.action: Always report IR absorptions in cm⁻¹ (e.g., C=O at 1700 cm⁻¹)

lower values indicate higher energy.error: Reversing the energy relationship - higher wavenumber = higher energy
lower values indicate higher energy.fix: Wavenumber is proportional to energy; higher cm⁻¹ means higher energy absorption
lower values indicate higher energy.action: Remember: wavenumber ∝ energy, so 3000 cm⁻¹ > 1000 cm⁻¹ in energy

persistent.gap: Not understanding wavenumber as the standard unit for IR spectroscopy
persistent.action: Practice reading IR spectra noting the cm⁻¹ scale decreases left to right

oh-stretch.name: O-H Stretching Absorption
oh-stretch.correct: O-H stretch appears as a broad absorption around 3200-3600 cm⁻¹

sharp peak at 1700 cm⁻¹.error: Confusing O-H with C=O - O-H is broad at higher wavenumber
sharp peak at 1700 cm⁻¹.fix: O-H stretch: broad peak 3200-3600 cm⁻¹; C=O stretch: sharp peak ~1700 cm⁻¹
sharp peak at 1700 cm⁻¹.action: O-H peaks are broad due to hydrogen bonding; C=O peaks are sharp

narrow peak at 3000 cm⁻¹.error: Describing O-H as narrow - hydrogen bonding makes it broad
narrow peak at 3000 cm⁻¹.fix: Hydrogen bonding between O-H groups causes a characteristically broad absorption
narrow peak at 3000 cm⁻¹.action: Broad peak in 3200-3600 cm⁻¹ region = O-H (or N-H)

absorption below 1500 cm⁻¹.error: Placing O-H in fingerprint region - O-H stretch is at high wavenumber
absorption below 1500 cm⁻¹.fix: O-H stretch occurs at high wavenumber (3200-3600 cm⁻¹), not in fingerprint region
absorption below 1500 cm⁻¹.action: Bond stretches involving H appear at high wavenumber due to low H mass

persistent.gap: Not recognising the characteristic broad O-H absorption pattern
persistent.action: Key identifier: broad absorption 3200-3600 cm⁻¹ indicates O-H (alcohol or carboxylic acid)

carbonyl-stretch.name: C=O Stretching Absorption
carbonyl-stretch.correct: C=O stretch appears as a strong sharp absorption around 1700 cm⁻¹

broad peak at 3400 cm⁻¹.error: Confusing C=O with O-H - C=O is sharp at lower wavenumber
broad peak at 3400 cm⁻¹.fix: C=O stretch: strong sharp peak ~1700 cm⁻¹; O-H: broad peak 3200-3600 cm⁻¹
broad peak at 3400 cm⁻¹.action: Look for sharp intense peak near 1700 cm⁻¹ to identify carbonyl

weak absorption at 1700 cm⁻¹.error: Underestimating C=O intensity - carbonyl absorption is characteristically strong
weak absorption at 1700 cm⁻¹.fix: C=O stretch is one of the strongest absorptions in IR due to the polar bond
weak absorption at 1700 cm⁻¹.action: C=O peaks are intense because the bond is highly polar

absorption at 2200 cm⁻¹.error: Wrong wavenumber region - C=O is at 1700 cm⁻¹, not 2200 cm⁻¹
absorption at 2200 cm⁻¹.fix: C=O absorbs around 1700 cm⁻¹; 2200 cm⁻¹ region is for triple bonds (C≡C, C≡N)
absorption at 2200 cm⁻¹.action: Remember: double bonds ~1600-1700 cm⁻¹; triple bonds ~2100-2200 cm⁻¹

persistent.gap: Not recognising the strong sharp carbonyl absorption
persistent.action: Carbonyl is the easiest group to spot: strong, sharp peak near 1700 cm⁻¹

ch-stretch.name: C-H Stretching Absorption
ch-stretch.correct: C-H stretch appears around 2850-3000 cm⁻¹ in most organic compounds

absorption above 3300 cm⁻¹.error: Placing C-H too high - only O-H and N-H appear above 3200 cm⁻¹
absorption above 3300 cm⁻¹.action: C-H is just below 3000 cm⁻¹; only O-H and N-H go higher

absorption below 1500 cm⁻¹.error: Confusing C-H stretch with C-H bending - stretch is at higher wavenumber
absorption below 1500 cm⁻¹.fix: C-H stretch is around 2850-3000 cm⁻¹; C-H bending modes appear below 1500 cm⁻¹
absorption below 1500 cm⁻¹.action: Stretching vibrations > bending vibrations in wavenumber

absorption at 1700 cm⁻¹.error: Confusing C-H with C=O region - C-H is at higher wavenumber
absorption at 1700 cm⁻¹.fix: C-H stretch: 2850-3000 cm⁻¹; C=O stretch: ~1700 cm⁻¹
absorption at 1700 cm⁻¹.action: C-H appears between C=O region and O-H region on the spectrum

persistent.gap: Not locating C-H stretch in the correct wavenumber region
persistent.action: C-H stretch is almost always present; look for peaks just below 3000 cm⁻¹

fingerprint-region.name: Fingerprint Region
fingerprint-region.correct: The fingerprint region below 1500 cm⁻¹ contains complex patterns unique to each molecule

region above 3000 cm⁻¹.error: Wrong location - fingerprint region is at LOW wavenumber
region above 3000 cm⁻¹.fix: Fingerprint region: below 1500 cm⁻¹; above 1500 cm⁻¹ contains functional group absorptions
region above 3000 cm⁻¹.action: High wavenumber = functional groups; low wavenumber = fingerprint

used to identify functional groups.error: Confusing fingerprint with functional group region
used to identify functional groups.fix: Fingerprint region identifies whole molecules by comparison; functional group region identifies specific groups
used to identify functional groups.action: Use fingerprint region to match spectra to reference compounds, not to identify groups

simple patterns that are easy to interpr.error: Oversimplifying fingerprint complexity - patterns are intricate
simple patterns that are easy to interpr.fix: Fingerprint region contains complex overlapping absorptions that are unique but hard to assign
simple patterns that are easy to interpr.action: Don't try to interpret individual fingerprint peaks - use for overall matching

persistent.gap: Not understanding the role of the fingerprint region
persistent.action: Fingerprint region is for identity confirmation by comparison, not group identification

bond-strength.name: Bond Strength and Absorption
bond-strength.correct: Stronger bonds and lighter atoms produce absorptions at higher wavenumber

weaker bonds absorb at higher wavenumber.fix: Stronger bonds vibrate faster and absorb at higher wavenumber (higher energy)
weaker bonds absorb at higher wavenumber.action: Think: stronger spring = faster vibration = higher frequency/wavenumber

heavier atoms absorb at higher wavenumbe.error: Reversing mass effect - lighter atoms vibrate faster
heavier atoms absorb at higher wavenumbe.fix: Lighter atoms (especially H) vibrate faster, absorbing at higher wavenumber
heavier atoms absorb at higher wavenumbe.action: X-H bonds appear at high wavenumber because H is the lightest atom

bond type doesn't affect absorption posi.error: Missing the relationship between bonding and absorption
bond type doesn't affect absorption posi.fix: Triple bonds absorb higher than double bonds which absorb higher than single bonds
bond type doesn't affect absorption posi.action: Compare: C≡C (~2200 cm⁻¹) > C=C (~1650 cm⁻¹) > C-C (~1000 cm⁻¹)

persistent.gap: Not connecting bond properties to absorption position
persistent.action: Remember: stronger bond OR lighter atoms → higher wavenumber

spectrum-interpretation.name: Spectrum Interpretation Strategy
spectrum-interpretation.correct: Interpret IR spectra by checking key functional group regions systematically

start analysis in fingerprint region.error: Wrong starting point - functional group region is more informative
start analysis in fingerprint region.fix: Start at high wavenumber checking for O-H, N-H, C-H, then move to carbonyl region

every peak must be assigned.error: Over-interpreting - focus on diagnostic peaks only
every peak must be assigned.fix: Focus on characteristic absorptions in functional group region; not every peak needs assignment
every peak must be assigned.action: Identify key functional groups from major peaks; ignore minor peaks

one peak confirms a functional group.error: Incomplete analysis - multiple peaks may be needed
one peak confirms a functional group.fix: Some groups show multiple related peaks (e.g., carboxylic acid: broad O-H AND C=O)
one peak confirms a functional group.action: Look for patterns: carboxylic acid = broad O-H + sharp C=O together

persistent.gap: Not using a systematic approach to interpret IR spectra
persistent.action: Always scan from high to low wavenumber, checking each functional group region

explanations.ir-absorption: IR radiation causes covalent bonds to vibrate (stretch and bend) at characteristic frequencies, enabling identification of bond types.
explanations.wavenumber: Wavenumber (cm⁻¹) is the standard unit for IR spectroscopy, with higher values indicating higher energy absorption.
explanations.oh-stretch: O-H stretching produces a broad absorption at 3200-3600 cm⁻¹, characteristic of alcohols and carboxylic acids.
explanations.carbonyl-stretch: C=O stretching produces a strong, sharp absorption around 1700 cm⁻¹, one of the most diagnostic peaks in IR.
explanations.ch-stretch: C-H stretching appears at 2850-3000 cm⁻¹ and is present in almost all organic compounds.
explanations.fingerprint-region: The region below 1500 cm⁻¹ contains complex patterns unique to each molecule, used for identity confirmation.
explanations.bond-strength: Stronger bonds and lighter atoms produce absorptions at higher wavenumber due to faster vibration frequencies.
explanations.spectrum-interpretation: Systematic analysis from high to low wavenumber identifies functional groups present in a compound.
